reviews.review_msg: Scott is a great and highly educated prof. Lectures are interesting and very relevant to current issues. The assignments allow the student to critically think and progressively build upon their skills. Scott's instructions can be unclear and vague at times but him and the TA provided clarity when necessary. Assignments need a rubric tho!!!

Dr. Lear is super kind, but lectures can be boring and dense. Assignments and presentations lacked clear criteria, and TAs marked tough. Exams are open book and AI is allowed. Final exam saved me. Stay organized, take detailed notes, and use office hours to succeed.
He's fine.

TA grading was very tough this semester, but the professor was very nice and helpful with questions. Course outline and grading are clear, but our paper outline and draft instructions were not that clear. Exams are open book but kind of tough, somehow ended up with an A- but i'm not complaining. Best tip is to organize notes and do good in tutorial

Dr. Lear was great. While his lectures could get boring at times which he admits as he is monotone and the lectures are 2 hours the content itself is fairly interesting. I respect his health initiatives and his ambition on trying to improve cardiovascular and mental health of others. Overall the course itself is fair and I recommended Scott

He himself is a great professor and he greatly cares about his student. His lectures are very long, so I would suggest keep close attention to topics he discusses multiple times, because those are likely to be on his exams.
what bum he is
Such a kind and smart professor, values his students. Always there to help.

I really enjoyed taking this class with Dr. Lear. He made classes 2 hours long instead of 3 by providing some work for us to do outside of class which I appreciated. He also related the content to his personal experiences and did his best to make lectures engaging. Overall, I would recommend taking a hsci course with him.
i didnt know he was chill like that

One of the best profs at SFU.This class is enjoyable and he makes me want to go to lecture. He makes his lectures funny, engaging and very clear. He has fill in blank slides to keep you attentive during lecture. His exams are open book and on canvas. He wants to see his students do well and it shows!! He is very fun and posts on TikTok!!

A good prof overall. Dr. Lear made content very straightforward and provided some personal insight into his own experience/work. Exams were fair, easy, and somewhat interesting. While online, the course format was not ideal (slides with recorded audio that could not be paused, sped up, etc.), but the course was not super content-heavy anyway.

i have had Scott for 2 classes now and he is such a chilled prof. Nothing intense in terms of workload or course content. HSCI 484 was very discussion heavy but it was always really interesting and fairly straightforward concepts you would have come across throughout your HSCI undergrad. Would definitely take another class with him again
scotts a great prof i would definitely take a class with him again. midterm and final were fair, presentation was also easy

During the pandemic, Scott could have made the class difficult for students but he chose to ease our burden as much possible with recorded lectures accessible anytime. He replies to emails fairly quickly and is open to questions. He can be boring but I suspect that is due to the material and he tries very hard to be interesting. Not a hard class.

Dr. Lear knows what he is talking about. His exams are extremely fair and nothing on them is a surprise. I did not find his lectures terribly boring because I enjoyed the content and found it very interesting. His personality is awesome - gotta check out his Tik Tok and Instagram accounts. Definitely one of the best profs I've had at SFU.

I'm not gonna lie, Scott has an incredibly monotone voice which makes it difficult to sit through the three hour lectures and his slides are packed with info. His exams are very fair and he only asks questions about things you've seen and he doesn't expect you to remember numbers. He is really knowledgable and always willing to answer questions!

Scott is a good/accessible prof. Lecs are PACKED with info so do your best to keep up and review . His midterm was very easy if you studied but final needed you to know about different aspects throughout the course so study hard it b/c there's 3 questions like that. There is a presentation and paper too (outline, draft and final version marked).

I very much enjoyed lectures with this prof, I think he's leagues above most lecturers in Hsci department! I feel he tested very fairly on the material that had been covered in class (aka: he doesn't test on something you've never seen in your life, and the universe was just supposed to supply you with the answer) Would take more classes with!

Dr. Lear is one of the best profs at SFU! Has done tons of research in cardiovascular disease prevention which makes his course more interesting! Truly cares about his students, and he's very approachable!

He's not the most exciting prof, but his tests are fair and tells you exactly what you need to know to do well in the class. Just for that, I say he's be leagues better than a ton of other profs. Be warned though, there WILL be a presentation and paper that may or may not affect your enthusiasm for school-- or life in general.

Scott is a fantastic lecturer who has real life experience with the material, and cares about his students. He's "dad joke" funny and encouraged participation in class. His tests are fair and his attempts at social media are informational and pretty entertaining. Definitely would take a class with him again.

Scott is my favorite prof at SFU, he always shows up with his 80 slide lectures and long silky hair before talking about job interviews for 20 minutes. He knows all there is to public health and will draw you in with his dynamic and powerful voice. During videos he cranks the speakers full blast so be warned! Amazing prof and I will take again!!!!

Worst professor in the HSCI department.  His lectures are unorganized and filled with dense slides that nobody understands (he doesn't even understand them). He is awful at helping/explaining things and steers you in the wrong direction. I would AVOID this class by all means.

basically the only problem i have with Dr. Lear is the 3 hours of monotone lecture... besides that, the lectures and information are simple, and the assignments aren't difficult. That said, i'm a slacker who never goes to class and considers a C+ a job well done, so take that as you will
Scott's lectures are long, but the content is interesting. His midterms seem easy, but the marking is hard.

His lectures were boring, and he had atleast 60-70 slides per lecture, making it difficult to study. However, this IS a 200 level class, and if you try hard, you can get a pretty good grade. Tutorial presentations were easy, as was the paper. Group discussions in class were fun too! Overall, it's a pretty easy class if u study!

the hardest 200 level HSCI class I've taken. He's really nice, but his lectures are SO boring and long, and he likes to give out WAY too much information, making it hard to study for his exams. Midterm was ok. its a passable course, just have to put a lot of effort into memorizing everything. Like bio. HSCI Arts majors beware!
the worst 200 level course. the midterm boring and very hard. the material is too much and cumulative. i wish i had know that he has changed and now makes the course dull and unbearable

Went to the first lecture and the last one, got all the fill in the blanks on the review day. Final is very straightforward, MC and short answer. The 10 page paper takes awhile to do, but I'd take that over midterms.
easy topic, materials were easy to digest & understand as well. only thing hard was 10 term paper. need to attend class to finish the lecture notes.

The final exam was fair and easy if you studied. The one thing I really hated about this course was that there was no textbook. It was hard to pick out what was needed from 100+ lecture slides per week with tons of graphs and stats.
while the class is easy overall, midterm is easy but final was a little hard (but ask ur TA for a question sheet for final it will help you alot).

Okay, so he is doing HSCI for the first time and I jsut felt that we were the guinea pigs because the lectures were later in the evening and towards the night and his exams didn't make sense. Trust me this prof. should teach the course but after re-organizing it. I think the department also responsilble, they made us do the final at night 7-10 pm
